comments.commentBody:
My mother had Parkinson's Disease. Had this policy been in effect 10 years ago, it would have kept her out of a nursing home. Her quality of life would have been vastly improved, her suffering much diminished. My father, my sister and I would have been saved immeasurable frustration and heartache.

(And, by the way, part-time in-home care would have cost the government a lot less than the full-time nursing home care that wound up being paid for by Medicaid.)

For any family of limited means with a chronically ill member, this is a very significant change.
What limits.  None are mentioned in the article.  Could it be that those "limits" are part of what will change because of this settlement?

Rick, what this means for PT, OT and SLP is that we will likely we able to use the KX modifier with greater  confidence. Now that we know that "maintaining skills" is valid for coverage with MCR we can bill over the 1880 cap with the KX and should we be audited we can make a strong case that preventing the deterioration of the patient is just as important as improving a condition in certain disease populations.
How are the therapy limits of $1880 for OT and $1880 for PT and ST combined affected? These limits still hinder recovery for stroke patients with chronic conditions like aphasia.

Corn and soy prices aren't really connected to feeding the poor, unless those poor people are drinking coke, while eating a McDonald's burger while driving their ethanol fueled car. Corn and soy are commodities and are connected to demand from the food and chemical industry and the much higher prices they'll pay for key ingredients in their product supply chain, not by the hunger of the poor. Ethanol and corn syrup are where the corn goes, and soy dyes and pig feed (meat for the rich in the first world not the poor) are where the soy goes. The corn and soy "commodities" are rarely part of a poor persons diet in the developing world.

Of course they checklist for international relations was not complete but at least the President mentioned developments in all continents except South America and Antartica. It's happenin' there, too.
Mitt talks about the southern Hemisphere like it is the new gold rush, but S.A. will come around to us more effectively than getting economically colonized; look at the newest trade treaty with Columbia (hard fought by Obama!) and consider the holes that Venezuela is digging itself in...and Mexico? get its illegal activities under control, amigos. Come around, come around, pals.
The Western Hemisphere will be led by the USA once it recognizes our hand of friendship THAT IS ALWAYS EXTENDED AND READY.

The best moment: Romney has had so many positions he claims he once called for sanctions! Obama ties global policies to domestic policies seamlessly and effortlessly.

Romney''s arms-length, indirect offshoring jobs to China, corporate raiding in Ann Romney's name is The Nation's cover story, out now. [http://wp.me/p1mBVu-1n2].

After the debate with Joe Biden and Paul Ryan I wrote a comment here about November 22, 1963 - how important the role of vice president may be.

After tonight's debate and seeing Mitt Romney's decision to play "follow the leader" with what President Obma's words were and what the president has done to lead this country we really need to scratch our heads. Romney tried to make people think what the President has done and will do as a leader in foreign policy is his idea. This was appalling. Mitt Romney is desperate to be President of the United States and will say anything to get there. Period.
Mitt Romney is a very confused man and is just as ill equipped as Paul Ryan to hold such a position.

In essence - not only do we have to worry about Paul Ryan being inept to step in as president if needed, we better worry big time about even considering for one moment that Mitt Romney would come close to being able to lead this country as president. It is very very scary.

Indeed. It is supremely ironic that we are expected to support Israel without limitation because it  is an ally in a fight with millions of people who would have no quarrel with us  had we not supported Israel in the first place--and for so long.

Yes, Robert, it's worth it, because it is morally right. The US cannot allow Ahmadinejad to finish the job that Hitler started. Life is about more than the economy and your summer home in Nova Scotia.

"The debate over Iran is, to a certain extent, a fight for the Jewish vote."

For what, 2.1% of the U.S. population? Is it really worth the cost in blood and treasure since 1948?

"Every time anyone says that Israel is our only friend in the Middle East, I can't help but think that before Israel, we had no enemies in the Middle East." ~ JOHN SHEEHAN, S.J.

8;40 p.m. Portland, OR   Compared to Barack Obama, the GOP candidate consistently licked his lips, swallowed heavily and (for most Americans who have not yet voted) came across through 90 minutes as a smirking and very uneasy guy who sent a signal that he is NOT ready for the Oval Office or the absurd partisan divides in Congress.  That the Salt Lake Tribune gave its support to the President made me wonder if the media made a gigantic mistake. I assume that I am not the only Democrat who has not filled out his ballot to find himself impressed by those Utah journalists.  I think I can hear Joe Biden hooting and throwing up both arms!
If we were honest, there's a lot to apologize for.  But we're "exceptional" with a "Manifest Destiny."  No need.
Or at least a little humility?
Even if he did make apologies on behalf of the United States, is that such a bad thing? We sure have a lot to apologise for and perhaps it's time to show some sincerity.
to VSR: very perceptive. Approval waves, empathetic anecdotes - you get it.

I thought President Obama so effectively addressed Gov. Romney's points that, eventually, Romney petered out and could only agree with the President. He also began to offer only rah-rah statements for what he would do for the country. Having watched the CNN audience approval wave, I saw that Romney eventually flat-lined. That approval wave also showed me that the time-worn empathetic anecdote, where a candidate speaks of some forlorn person he has met on the campaign trail, is dead. It worked for years, beginning with Ronald Reagan. But it is now seen for what it is: a cynical trick to move an audience toward the wannabe political "empath." Each time this device was used, the wave descended. I have no doubt that these two candidates are empathetic; there's no need to contest that. But what we need is a President with effective strategies and strength. Tonight, President Obama showed himself clearly to be the President we need -- again.

Willard flustered and blustered, early and often. Obama stiff-armed him effectively. Schieffer was neither a pushover nor a bully.

I think Obama gained votes tonight.

And more to the point--which of them can sit down with world leaders and not insult them?  Romney's already demonstrated his "skill" at dealing with foreign leaders by embarrassing the US with his tactlessness and openly racist remarks.

The differences are huge indeed, and this is what must be explained and emphasized.  Why does a columnist want to write about where they agree? What is the real reason for writing about any so called agreement between these 2 candidates above all?

In my all-republican-run state, with its ALEC friends, an effort was made this past year to raise taxes on the poor and middle class while giving mammoth tax cuts to the richest among us. It failed only because past republicans had made it so hard to raise ANY taxes by law. But the guv and her party promise to be back to do it this year. (When our governor was a senator, she pushed for no income taxes and a 30% sales tax to run government. That's the republican way, and it would impoverish many while pouring money into the accounts of billionaires.)

But in Oklahoma, she has more power than she did in DC. Our child poverty rate increased 9% in just the last year (!) to nearly one-third of our children under republican plans and policies. And services will see more cuts as the continual push to please corporations and the wealthy continues. If that's what you want, that's the republicans, whether state or national.

That phrase about obstructing and defeating Obama is the reality which will not allow progress, And Romney's litany about working with a Democratic congress is of course so much rethorics, if not lies.
Bi-partisanship works if there is understanding on the need to work for a better society, and compromise will mostly come from the Democratic/lLiberal side of the aisle, regardless who runs the show.
It is the same in Israel.
David Gutholc
Ramat Hasharon Isarel

Nothing will change for as long as our elected officials are elected by the people but beholden to the interests represented by K Street. Nothing.

There is a huge difference between Romney and Obama on taxes. Obama has desperately been trying to preserve the social contract. Romney is on a mission to obliterate it. Anyone who doesn't believe it is fooling themselves. Romney isn't divulging which tax loopholes he'd close because it would cause a landslide for President Obama.

If you want to know what Romney intends to do, on any given topic, head on over to the Mother Jones website and David Corn's article with the famous secret video* of Romney speaking to donors at a private home in Florida. Yes, the 47% video. That's where the real Romney was captured and will forever live.

Ronald Reagan's GOP, whatever glorified memories of it we have created for ourselves, is gone. Today's GOP is made up of two extreme groups, theocrats and plutocrats. They have stopped at nothing, including jeopardizing our economy over the debt ceiling talks, in order to achieve their goal of obstructing and defeating President Obama. In the states, the GOP has been on a mission to destroy our unions, privatize public institutions or refuse to participate in Federal programs (healthcare) - to the detriment of the public.

There is a huge difference between Romney and Obama. Huge.

* http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2012/09/secret-video-romney-private-...
Mitt can sell anything, even onvince people to sell their own souls, if they are foolish enough to buy into his lies. He is a salesman. Not a President but a business salesman.
Probably represents WHERE the debate took place, it's close to where many retiring seniors live?

I've been using Windows 8 for about 6 months now and it's ok. My main problem is that it is very unstable. My year old laptop crashes consistently where it didn't with the previous version. Plus the blue-screen-of-death gives no real data about what caused the crash. I may go back to Windows 7 just to replace the stability.
But you see, people think the same of Obama.
John Bolton!! omg!
Why, zezee?

Mr. Romney has t o respect to average American voter. If his aim was not appear as war monger who is ready to throw bombs aimlessly he might succeeded by agreeing almost to all President Obama's foreign affair positions. I trust that most American will not buy his sudden 180 degree turn around. They should examine his previous positions and they should just look who is on his team. Liz Cheney, John Bolton and Sandor among other. Does anybody with IQ of 70 or more will believe such shap shifting man with any backbone or core beliefs.

Yes he is. My husband's a teacher - the old bells were ringing in our house here in Wisconsin tonight with that line. It'll be through the whole country if Romney and Ryan get in. So teachers - beware if red takes the country.

Governor Walker was paid off to try to turn Wisconsin red and look what happened here? Although the courts have now declared many parts of
Walker's Act 10 plan unconstitutional....for now.
I cast my vote before the debate; because I want a cool hand sitting across from the Red Phone, and not a trigger-happy wannabe Commander in Chief.

In his closing remarks, I think I heard Romney say, "I'd like to be your leader.....I'd like to be your president..."

Ah, yes, wouldn't he though?

In your dreams, Slippery Mitt !!!
Just like Ann, "I love you women!" Interesting. Pandering to make up for their mistakes.
Yes - Romney loves teachers . . . but not the organizations that try to improve the teaching and learning environment for teachers and their students.

So many great lines by Obama tonight, but Romney made me crack up (unintentionally) when he ended the debate by saying "I love teachers!  I love teachers!"  It was so weird, even Bob Schieffer had to mumble "yes, we all love teachers . . . "   hilarious!!!
And they've put a :- ( on the blue screen of death which happens with frightening regularity. I preferred the old sad Mac back in the day.

You're dead wrong.  President Obama was magnificent tonight.  He demonstrated vast intelligence and knowledge, clear and concise thought processes, respect, firmness, and a presidential demeanor.  Those who say that the president showed disdain for Mitt Romney are blind or don't know much about body language and facial features.  They are engaging in wishful thinking.
We all know what Bob ment.
@Jack Yes, we know exactly what Bob, former golfing buddy of George W. Bush, meant.

Involuntary "politically incorrect" mental process by the moderator with his lips telling the Truth here,
was supposed to say "Osama bin Laden" instead :

"MR. SCHIEFFER: All right. Let me go to Governor Romney because you talked about Pakistan and what needs to be done there. General Allen, our commander in Afghanistan, says that Americans continue to die at the hands of groups who are supported by Pakistan. We know that Pakistan has arrested the doctor who helped us catch *Obama’s — bin Laden.* It still provides safe haven for terrorists, yet we continue to give Pakistan billions of dollars. Is it time for us to divorce Pakistan? "

This was all new information to him.
I really appeared as if he had just studied up on all this foreign policy stuff this weekend.

Maybe I'm giving Romney too much credit for geopolitical sophistication, but I'm guessing that his point is that Iran already has the upper hand in Iraq and that Syria will give the Ayatollahs an outlet on the Mediterranean.

If that's so, then so much for the neocon "stratergy" of getting rid of Saddam so we could turn Iraq into a democracy, just like Texas or Oklahoma.

Anyway, I came away from the debate reassured that Obama is the commander-in-chief we need--the best guarantee possible in these parlous times that we can muddle through the next four years without one more diastrous American war in the Middle East.
He probably meant the Mediterranean Sea.  Not that I am going to vote for Romney, but enough about the sea already.

A big blunder for Romney was geography. He said Syria was Iran's route to the sea. Iran has a long coastline, and Iraq is in between Syria and Iran. Romney is not only all over the map, but he never looks at one.
